class.description: Represents the attributes of an Element object.

constructor.description: Represents the attributes of an Element object.

property.name: name
property.remarks: Due to the nature of DOM Element attributes, the name value must be unique across attributes attached to the same element node.
property.description: Name of the attribute object.
property.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/attributes.html

property.name: ownerElement
property.remarks: Because attributes are meaningless unless they are bound to an Element, this property allows you to find the node that an attribute is attached to. If this attribute is not yet attached to a node, the value of this property is set to null.
property.description: Parent node that the attribute is attached to.

property.name: specified
property.remarks:
If true, indicates that this attribute value was explicitly set from a source XML document or via a DOM method call. Otherwise, the specified property is false.

For example, if a document has an element definition with a "width" attribute with a default value of "3", the specified property for the Attr of the element is set to false when the document loads. If the value of the is subsequently changed, this property will change to true. You can only revert the specified property back to its original value by deleting the attribute from its parent node so that the DTD recreates the default attribute.
property.description: If true, specifies that the attribute was explicitly created.
property.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/attributes.html

property.name: value
property.remarks: Returns and sets the value of the attribute as a String. Replaces entity references with their values. In addition to methods for retrieving Attr objects, the Element object has methods for accessing the value of an attribute without having to deal directly with the Attr object.
property.description: Value of the attribute.
property.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/attributes.html

class.remarks:
Attributes are properties of Elements and do not have their own identities. Although an Attr is a descendant of a Node, an Attr is not placed in a parentNode, nextSibling or previousSibling, and its own instances of those properties are null. Additionally, an Attr objects may only be a child of an Element object.

Set the value of an attribute either via the DOM, from a source document, or from a DTD or other XML Schema. If a declaration for an attribute exists that defines a default value, and the attribute in question does not exist, the attribute will be automatically added with the given value. Usually, however, an attribute does not exist until it is explicitly added.

class.description: Represents a CDATA section in a XML/HTML document

constructor.description: Represents a CDATA section in a XML/HTML document

class.remarks:
Creates and represents CDATA sections. CDATA sections escape entire blocks of text, such as XML fragments, source code, or other content that would be interpreted as XML markup. The only content within a CDATA section that is interpreted is the string "]]>", which represents the end of a CDATA section.

The DOM specification describes CDATA sections as:

CDATA sections may occur anywhere character data may occur; they are used to escape blocks of text containing characters which would otherwise be recognized as markup. CDATA sections begin with the string "<![CDATA[" and end with the string "]]>".

While the Node object - from which this object inherits - supports the normalize method, this will not work on adjacent CDATASection nodes.

class.description: Object for accessing and processing character data in the DOM.

constructor.description: Object for accessing and processing character data in the DOM.

property.name: data
property.remarks: The data property does not have a size limitation, but data is subject to the limitations of the size of a String object. If the content data is too large, use substringData to retrieve the character data in chunks.
property.description: Character data of the current node.

property.name: length
property.remarks: Length of the content available from the data property or the substringData method. If the content of data is empty, the value of length will be zero.
property.description: Length of the content of the data property or substringData method.

method.name: appendData

parameter.name: arg
parameter.description: String to append.

exception.description: Raises a NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED error if the node is read-only.

method.remarks: Appends the specified string to the end of the current character data content, which will then be available through the data property.
method.description: Appends the specified string to the node text.
method.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/data.html

method.name: deleteData

parameter.name: offset
parameter.description: Character offset inside the content from which to start deleting.

parameter.name: count
parameter.description: Number of characters to delete. If the range of characters is greater than the length of the content of the node, then all characters from offset to the end of the string are deleted.

exception.description: Raises a NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED error if the node is read-only.
Raises an INDEX_SIZE_ERR error if either the offset or count is negative or if offset is greater than the length of the Text or Comment.

method.remarks: Removes the specified range of characters from content of the node and shifts any remaining text downward. if the characters are successfully deleted, updates the properties of the node to indicate the new content and size.
method.description: Deletes the indicated range of text.
method.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/data.html

method.name: insertData

parameter.name: offset
parameter.description: Character offset inside the content at which to insert the new string.

parameter.name: arg
parameter.description: String to insert.

exception.description: Raises a NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED error if the node is read-only.
Raises an INDEX_SIZE_ERR if either the offset or count is negative or if offset is greater than the length of the Text or Comment.

method.remarks: Performs the opposite of deleteData.
method.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/data.html
method.description: Inserts the supplied text at the indicated character offset

method.name: replaceData

parameter.name: offset
parameter.description: Character offset inside the content at which to start the replacement.

parameter.name: count
parameter.description: Number of characters to replace. If the range of characters is greater than the length of the content of the node, all characters from offset to the end of the string are replaced.

parameter.name: arg
parameter.description: Text string to replace the specified range.

exception.description: Raises a NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED error if the node is read-only.
Raises an INDEX_SIZE_ERR error if either the offset or count is negative or if offset is greater than the length of the Text or Comment.

method.remarks: Replaces a specific range of text within the content of the node with the supplied string. Equivilant to invoking deleteData, followed by insertData using the same offset.
method.description: Substitutes the indicated range of text with the supplied string
method.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/data.html

method.name: substringData

parameter.name: offset
parameter.description: The character offset inside the content to return.

parameter.name: count
parameter.description: The number of characters to return.

exception.description: Throws a DOMException specifying NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED if the node is read-only. Throws an INDEX_SIZE_ERR
Throws a DOMException specifying INDEX_SIZE_ERR if either the offset or count is negative or if offset is greater than the length of the Text or Comment.

method.remarks: Often used for extracting easily-processable regions of text, this method extracts a region of text from the node's content and returns it.
method.description: Returns the specified range of text.
method.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/data.html
method.return-description: Returns a string of text from the specified range.

class.remarks:
CharacterData provides a set of attributes and methods for accessing character data in the DOM. This object is always inherited by other objects that require this functionality, such as Text and CDATASection.

CDATASection methods manipulate text ranges and considers that the content of the node may be larger than the limits of the String object, so CDATASection methods all work with numeric character offsets and text ranges. You should already know the ranges that you will need before invoking these methods.

The content of this node is represented as UTF-16.

class.description: Represents a comment in a XML/HTML document.

constructor.description: Represents a comment in a XML/HTML document.

class.remarks:
Represents the contents of an HTML or XML comment, which begins with the token <!-- and ends with -->. The contents of this node are any characters that exist between those two tokens.

Comment inherits its capabilities from CharacterData. See CharacterData for more information on the methods and properties available via the Comment object.

class.description: Single value for a CSS style.

constructor.description: Single value for a CSS style.

property.name: primitiveType
property.description: Holds the value of a constant. See Remarks for possible values.
property.remarks:
The following list of constants describes the possible values for primitiveType:

  • CSS_UNKNOWN=0 - Unrecognized or unparseable value.
  • CSS_NUMBER=1 - Number with no units.
  • CSS_PERCENTAGE=2- Percentage.
  • CSS_EMS=3 - Relative length in ems.
  • CSS_EXS=4 - Relative length in exs.
  • CSS_PX=5 - Length in pixels.
  • CSS_CM=6 - Absolute length in centimeters.
  • CSS_MM=7 - Absolute length in millimeters.
  • CSS_IN=8 - Absolute length in inches.
  • CSS_PT=9 - Absolute length in points.
  • CSS_PC=10 - Absolute length in picas.
  • CSS_DEG=11 - Angle in degrees.
  • CSS_RAD=12 - Angle in radians.
  • CSS_GRAD=13 - Angle in grads.
  • CSS_MS=14 - Time in milliseconds.
  • CSS_S=15 - Time in seconds.
  • CSS_HZ=16 - Frequency in hertz.
  • CSS_KHZ=17 - Frequency in kilohertz.
  • CSS_DIMENSION=18 - Dimension without units.
  • CSS_STRING=19 - String.
  • CSS_URI=20 - URI.
  • CSS_IDENT=21 - Unique identifier.
  • CSS_ATTR=22 - Attribute function.
  • CSS_COUNTER=23 - Counter.
  • CSS_RECT=24 - Rectangle.
  • CSS_RGBCOLOR=25 - Color (RGB).

property.description: Text for the current CSS rule.
property.remarks:
If you specify an invalid value for cssText, the property may throw one of the following DOMExceptions:

  • HIERARCHY_REQUEST_ERR - CSS rule is not legal in the current location in the CSS style sheet.
  • INVALID_MODIFICATION_ERR - New value for the CSS rule is for a different type than the previous type.
  • NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR - The CSS rule or its parent CSS style sheet is read-only.
  • SYNTAX_ERR - CSS syntax error.

The following constants are valid values for cssValueType:

  • CSS_INHERIT=0 - Indicates that the value of the CSS style attribute is inherited.
  • CSS_PRIMITIVE_VALUE=1 - Indicates that the value of the CSS style attribute is a primitive value.
  • CSS_VALUE_LIST=2 - Indicates that the CSS value actually contains a list of values.
  • CSS_CUSTOM=3 - Indicates that the CSS value is of a type not supported by CSS or DOM standards.

property.name: doctype
property.remarks: Every document can contain a Document Type Declaration (DTD) that defines document structure and entity references for the document. The doctype property represents the state of this document's DTD, which is either a DocumentType object, or null, if no DTD is specified.
property.description: Document Data Type (DTD) associated with this document.

property.name: documentElement
property.remarks:
documentElement is a convenience property for accessing the contents of a document.

Without the

documentElement property, you would have to write doc.childNodes.item(0) or doc.childNodes[0] to access the contents of a document, instead of just typing doc.documentElement.
property.description: Root element in a document.

For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/document.html

property.description: Array of all embedded objects in the document.

property.name: expando
property.remarks: Use expando to help catch typos and case-sensitivity issues in your JavaScript.

property.name: fgColor
property.remarks: Use the fgColor property of the <body> tag to initially set the color of the document text. To set this property, use the color properties of HTMLBodyElement to set the color in the <head> tag.
property.description: Font color of the document text.

property.name: fileCreatedDate
property.description: Date that the document was created.

property.name: fileModifiedDate
property.description: Date that the document was last modified.

property.name: fileSize
property.description: File size (in bytes) of the document.

property.description: Array of all of the Forms in the document.

property.name: frames
property.remarks: Although the Frames array is read-only, you can modify the individual Frame elements.
property.description: Array of all of the Frames in the document.

property.name: height
property.description: Height of the entire HTML document (in pixels).

property.name: ids
property.remarks: Although the Ids array is read-only, you can modify the individual Id elements.
property.description: Array of style properties in the document set by the Id attribute.

property.name: images
property.remarks: Although the Images array is read-only, you can modify the individual Image elements.
property.description: Array of Image objects in the document.

property.name: implementation
property.description: Object that specifies whether or not and at what level the browser supports the specified feature.

property.name: lastModified
property.description: Date that the document was last modified.

method.name: createAttribute

parameter.name: name
parameter.description: Name of the attribute to create.

exception.description: Raises an INVALID_CHARACTER_ERR error if the specified qualified name contains an illegal character.

browser.description: Safari will create the attribute, but you will have to use nodeValue to set its value.

method.example:
Using createAttribute

var ele=document.createElement('a');
                    var href=document.createAttribute('href');
                    href.value='http://mozref.com';
                    ele.setAttributeNode(href);
                    ele.appendChild(document.createTextNode('Mozilla AOM Reference'));

For more examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/attributes3.html
method.remarks:
Although Attribute objects can only be bound to Element objects, they can be created by a Document object and later be bound to an element using setAttributeNode.

While an Attr node may contain several different properties, this method only populates the nodeName property and sets the attribute value set to null. The localName, prefix, and namespaceURI properties are all set to null. To set those values, use the createAttributeNS method.
method.description: Creates a new Attr node
method.return-description: Returns a new Attr node object.

method.name: createAttributeNS

parameter.name: namespaceURI
parameter.description: The namespace of the new attribute.

parameter.name: qualifiedName
parameter.description: The qualified name (e.g. rdf:about) of the attribute to create.

exception.description: Raises an INVALID_CHARACTER_ERR error if the specified qualified name contains an illegal character.

Raises NAMESPACE_ERR error if the qualifiedName is malformed, if the qualifiedName has a prefix and the namespaceURI is null, if the qualifiedName has a prefix that is "xml" and the namespaceURI is different from "http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace", or if the qualifiedName is "xmlns" and the namespaceURI is different from "http://www.w3.org/2000/xmlns/".

method.remarks:
Similar to createAttribute, createAttributeNS creates a new Attr within the current document, but createAttributeNS uses namespaces and can populate many of the attribute properties using the specified namespaceURI, qualifiedName objects.

This method will do its best to populate as many propertys as it can, to the best of its ability. For more information about these properties, please see their respective objects.
method.description: Creates a new Attr using a namespace.
method.return-description: Returns a new Attr node object created with a namespace.

method.name: createCDATASection

parameter.name: data
parameter.description: The text to wrap up into a new CDATASection object.

exception.description: Raises a NOT_SUPPORTED_ERR error if the current document is an HTML document.

method.example:
Using createCDATASection

var cdata=document.createCDATASection(
                    'this &p invalid markup &exists in this CDATA & section'
                    );
                    var obj=document.getElementById('header');
                    obj.appendChild(cdata);
method.remarks: Creates a new CDATASection object within the current document, representing a region of uninterpreted content. Any text within this object, with the exception of the string "]]>", will not be encoded or otherwise interpreted by the DOM engine.
method.description: Creates a new CDATASection node
method.return-description: Returns a new CDATASection node.

method.name: createComment

parameter.name: data
parameter.description: The text to include in the comment.

method.example:
Using createComment

var comment=document.createComment('this text will not appear in HTML');
                    var obj=document.getElementById('header');
                    obj.appendChild(comment);
method.remarks: Creates a new Comment object that can be used for adding a region of commented text for inclusion into the current document. Any text within this object, with the exception of the string "-->" will be protected within the document.
method.description: Creates a new Comment node
method.return-description: Returns a new Comment node.

method.name: createDocumentFragment
method.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/docfrag.html
method.description: Creates an empty DocumentFragment object
method.return-description: Returns a new empty DocumentFragment object.

method.name: createElement

parameter.name: tagName
parameter.description: The tag name of the element to be created.

exception.description: Raises an INVALID_CHARACTER_ERR error if the specified name contains an illegal character.

browser.description: IE also supports the syntax "createElement('<p>')".

method.example:
Using createElement

var newList=document.createElement('ol');
                    newList.setAttribute('class', 'features');
                    document.getElementById('sidebar').appendChild(newList);

For additional examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/basics.html
method.remarks:
Use createElement to create a new Element to later include in the Document. Returns a new Element, complete with any default attributes that are defined by the the DocumentType object, which represents the DTD for the document.

Because createElement does not support namespaces, the localName, prefix, and namespaceURI properties are all set to null. To create elements with namespaces (e.g. XUL elements), use createElementNS.
method.description: Creates a new Element node of the type specified by tagName (e.g. li element.)
method.return-description: Returns a new Element object as specified by tagName.

method.name: createElementNS

parameter.name: namespaceURI
parameter.description: Namespace of the new element.

parameter.name: qualifiedName
parameter.description: Qualified name (e.g. myns:element) of the element to create.

exception.description: Raises an INVALID_CHARACTER_ERR error if the specified qualified name contains an illegal character.

Raises a NAMESPACE_ERR error if the qualifiedName is malformed, if the qualifiedName has a prefix and the namespaceURI is null, or if the qualifiedName has a prefix that is "xml" and the namespaceURI is different from "http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace"

method.example:
Using createElementNS

var newButton=document.createElement(
                    'http://www.mozilla.org/keymaster/gatekeeper/there.is.only.xul',
                    'xul:button'
                    );
method.remarks:
Use createElementNS to create a new element with a namespace in a document.

By simply supplying both the namespace URI and the qualified name of the element, the following values are extracted to create a fully-formed namespace-aware element:

Element properties set by <code>createElementNS</code>PropertyleftValueleftlocalName The local name of this tag name, extracted from qualifiedNamenamespaceURInamespaceURInodeNamequalifiedNameprefix The namespace prefix extracted from qualifiedName, or null if this element does not define a prefix tagNamequalifiedName
method.description: Creates a new Element node with a namespace.
method.return-description: Returns a new Element object as specified by tagName and created with a namespace.

method.name: createEntityReference

parameter.name: name
parameter.description: Name of the new entity reference.

exception.description: Raises an INVALID_CHARACTER_ERR error if the specified name contains illegal characers. Raises a NOT_SUPPORTED_ERR error if the current document is an HTML document.

method.remarks:
Creates a new EntityReference object with the specified name.

If the requested entity name is already known to the current document, the returned EntityReference object's children are set to the same as the corresponding Entity. This makes creating entity references in your document much easier, since it eliminates a step.
method.description: Creates a new EntityReference object
method.return-description: Returns a new XML EntityReference object.

method.description: Creates a new Event object to be used by the fireEvent method.
method.return-description: Returns a new Event object.

method.name: createProcessingInstruction

parameter.name: target
parameter.description: Name, or "target", of the processing instruction to create.

parameter.name: data
parameter.description: Data to store in the processing instruction.

exception.description: Raises an INVALID_CHARACTER_ERR error if the specified target contains illegal characers.
Raises a NOT_SUPPORTED_ERR error if the current document is an HTML document.

method.example:
Using createProcessingInstruction

document.createProcessingInstruction(
                    'xml-stylesheet',
                    'href="docbook.xsl" type="text/xsl"'
                    );
method.remarks: Creates a new ProcessingInstruction at the beginning of the current document using the specified target and data values.
method.description: Creates a new ProcessingInstruction node with the specified target and data strings.
method.return-description: Returns a new ProcessingInstruction node.

method.name: createStyleSheet

parameter.name: url
parameter.description: URL to create the styleSheet object from. Default is to create an empty styleSheet.

parameter.name: index
parameter.description: Index in the document to add the styleSheet. Default is to add the styleSheet to the end of the document.

method.remarks: IE only. Supported in IE4+.
method.description: Creates a new StyleSheet object.
method.return-description: Returns a new styleSheet node object.
method.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/style.html

method.name: createTextNode

parameter.name: data
parameter.description: Text to include in the Text node.

method.example:
Using createTextNode

var newEle=document.createElement('b');
                    var newText=document.createTextNode('this text is bold');
                    newEle.appendChild(newText);

For additional examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/basics.html
method.remarks: Creates a new Text node for insertion into the DOM tree. Text nodes represent text within a document as a child of another element, such as the document content that is displayed to the user.
method.description: Creates a new Text node.
method.return-description: Returns a new Text node object.

method.name: elementFromPoint

parameter.name: x
parameter.description: Horizontal (x) position (in pixels) of the element to return.

parameter.name: y
parameter.description: Vertical (x) position (in pixels) of the element to return.

method.remarks: IE only. Supported in IE4+.
method.description: Returns the element found at the specified x, y location in the document.
method.return-description: Returns the element found at the specified x, y location in the document.

method.name: execCommand

parameter.name: command
parameter.description: Command to execute.

parameter.name: UI
parameter.description: Specify true to display a user interface. Default is false.

parameter.name: value
parameter.description: Value to assign, depending on the command.

method.description: Executes the specified command on the document.
method.return-description: Returns true if the command is successful.

method.name: focus
method.remarks: IE only. Supported in IE5.5+.
method.description: Gives focus to the document and fires the onfocus event handler.
method.return-description: The current document with focus on it.

method.name: getElementById

parameter.name: id
parameter.description: Id of the element to get.

browser.description: In addition to returning the element with the specified "id", IE will also return an element with a "name" that equals the specified "id".

method.example:
Using getElementById

var emailproperty=document.getElementById("email-textbox");
                    var emailAddress=emailproperty.getAttribute("value");

For additional examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/basics.html
method.remarks:
Use getElementById to avoid traversing multiple child nodes to retrieve a value.

Use a naming convention to assign unique Element id's so that you can easily retrieve information from the object model of your document without having add the id's later.

The DOM Level 2 Core specification does not define specific behavior for multiple elements with the same id, but Mozilla-based browsers will return the first element with specified id.
method.description: Returns the Element node that matches the given ID.
method.return-description: Returns the Element object node that matches the given ID.

parameter.name: name
parameter.description: The name of the element you want to access/manipulate

method.name: getElementsByTagName

parameter.name: tagname
parameter.description: Tag name of the elements to return. Specify "*" to return all tags.

browser.description: Does not work in IE 5.0 on Windows.

method.example:
Using getElementsByTagName

// Assume there is only one  in the document
                    var body=document.getElementsByTagName("body").item(0);
                    var paragraphs=body.getElementsByTagName("p");

For additional examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/basics.html
method.remarks: Returns a list of elements in the document that have the specified tagName. The returned NodeList is sorted in the order the elements were found during a depth-first preorder traversal through the node tree.
method.description: Returns an array of Element nodes with the specified tag name.
method.return-description: Returns an array of Element nodes with the specified tag name.

method.name: getElementsByTagNameNS

parameter.name: namespaceURI
parameter.description: Namespace of the elements to return. Specify "*" to return all tags.

parameter.name: localName
parameter.description: Tag name of the elements to return (minus the namespace prefix). Specify "*" to return all tags.

method.example:
Using getElementsByTagNameNS

var commands=document.getElementsByTagNameNS(
                    'http://www.mozilla.org/keymaster/gatekeeper/there.is.only.xul',
                    'command'
                    );
method.remarks: Like getElementsByTagName, this method returns a NodeList of elements found in the current document that match the specified tag name. However, this version of the method takes both a namespace URI and local name of the element's tag name.
method.description: Returns the Element nodes with the specified element name and namespace.
method.return-description: Returns the Element nodes with the specified element name and namespace.

method.name: getSelection
method.remarks: Netscape only. Supported in NS4+.
method.description: Returns the text currently selected by the user.
method.return-description: Returns the text currently selected by the user.

method.name: importNode

parameter.name: importedNode
parameter.description: Node to import.

parameter.name: deep
parameter.description: If true, indicates that all child nodes of the import node should be imported as well.

exception.description: Raises a NOT_SUPPORTED_ERR error if the node type being imported is not supported by the current document.

method.remarks: importNode is similar to cloneNode, except that importNode works across documents. importNode attempts to copy as much information about a node as possible, although different documents may be of different types (e.g. XML and HTML) or have different DTD's.
method.description: Imports a node from a different document.
method.return-description: Returns a node from a different document.

method.name: isSupported

parameter.name: feature
parameter.description: Name of the feature.

parameter.name: version
parameter.description: Version of the feature.

method.remarks: Tests whether a node supports the specified feature. Similar to the DOMImplementation.hasFeature method and takes the same feature names. If version is null, returns true if any version of the feature is supported.
method.description: Returns true if the specified feature and version are supported.
method.return-description: Returns true if the specified feature and version are supported.

method.name: open

parameter.name: mimeType
parameter.description: MIME Type for the new document. IE only.

parameter.name: name

class.remarks:
This object interface represents an entire HTML or XML document. For most applications, this will be the effective root of an object tree, since elements, text nodes, and other XML-based source content cannot exist outside of a Document object. This object contains all the factory methods necessary to create additional objects along these lines. All nodes created with this document have their ownerDocument property set to this one.

Within Mozilla (either with XUL running in a chrome environment, or HTML working within a browser) the Document object representing the current document is usually set automatically to the global document variable. This global variable is often referenced in sample documentation, and can be used within your code as well.

class.remarks:
This is a lightweight Document object that is used when the standard Document interface is too heavy to use. The Range object uses DocumentFragment objects extensively, so that it can extract and store ranges of DOM nodes without creating an entirely new document.

A DocumentFragment behaves like a conventional Node with all of the same methods, except that a DocumentFragment does not have to be fully-formed XML and can be used to represent partly-formed or subsets of documents.

class.description: Represents the <!DOCTYPE> of a document.

constructor.description: Represents the <!DOCTYPE> of a document.

property.name: entities
property.remarks: List of all of the general entities defined within this DTD. This includes both internal and external entities. Any duplicates are discarded, with the first occurance of a named entity being preserved. Every key value within this property uses the Entity interface.
property.description: List of entities defined in the DTD.

property.name: internalSubset
property.remarks: This value contains the string contained between the "[" and "]" characters. Not all DocumentType objects will contain a value in this property, which can rely on an external file for defining entities.
property.description: Contents of the DTD subset

property.name: name
property.remarks: Name of the DTD, which is represented in XML documents as the name immediately after the <![CDATA[<!DOCTYPE]]> keyword.
property.description: Name of the DTD.
property.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/attributes.html

property.name: notations
property.remarks: List of all the notations defined in this DTD. Like entities, any duplicates are discarded, keeping only the first occurance of any duplicated key.
property.description: List of notations defined in this DTD

property.name: publicId
property.remarks: Public identifier of the document type definition. This is usually a common identifier used to represent a kind of content. For instance, the publicId value for an XHTML document could be "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN".
property.description: The public identifier of the external subset

property.name: systemId
property.remarks: This is the system identifier, or filename, of the document type definition itself. This is usually a path to a file on disk or a URI pointing at the DTD.
property.description: The system identifier of the external subset

class.remarks:
This represents the doctype for a Document. If a document has a doctype, it will be a reference to an instantiation of this interface. This object represents all the information stored in the ]]> section of a source document.

Throughout the rest of the documentation in this object, the following sample DTD will be used to illustrate how the various properties work.

]> ]]>

class.description: Interface defining error codes for DOM-related processing exceptions.

constructor.description: Interface defining error codes for DOM-related processing exceptions.

property.name: INDEX_SIZE_ERR
property.description: Thrown if the index or size is either negative or greater than the allowed value.

property.name: DOMSTRING_SIZE_ERR
property.remarks: Constant defining the error code for when the specified range of text won't fit in a String value.
property.description: Code used when the specified range of text cannot fit into a String.

property.name: HIERARCHY_REQUEST_ERR
property.remarks: When a node is inserted somewhere in the DOM tree where it doesn't belong (for instance, a Attr node as a child of Text), this error code is used.
property.description: Code used when a node is inserted where it doesn't belong

property.name: WRONG_DOCUMENT_ERR
property.remarks: This code is used when a node is used in a different document than the one in which it exists.
property.description: Code used when the node being specified does not exist in the current document

property.name: INVALID_CHARACTER_ERR
property.remarks: When an invalid or illegal character is used in some method, or for an attribute, this error code is used. This is often used for element or attribute names, for instance.
property.description: Code used when an illegal character is used

property.name: NO_DATA_ALLOWED_ERR
property.remarks: This code is used when an attempt is made to supply data to a node that does not support data.
property.description: Code used when data is supplied to a node that does not support it

property.name: NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR
property.remarks: This code is used when an attempt is made to modify an object that cannot be modified.
property.description: Code used when modifications are made to an object where modifications are not permitted

property.name: NOT_FOUND_ERR
property.remarks: This code is used when a node is used that does not exist in the context in which the operation is taking place.
property.description: Code used when a node is referenced that does not exist in the current context

property.name: NOT_SUPPORTED_ERR
property.remarks: This code is used when the current implementation does not support the type of object or datatype requested.
property.description: Code used when the implementation does not support the requested type or object

property.name: INUSE_ATTRIBUTE_ERR
property.remarks: When an attribute is added when it is already in use elsewhere, this error code is used.
property.description: Code used when an added attribute that already exists elsewhere

property.name: INVALID_STATE_ERR
property.remarks: This code is used when an attempt is made to use an object that is no longer usable, or no longer exists.
property.description: Code used when an object is used that no longer exists

property.name: SYNTAX_ERR
property.remarks: This code is used when there is some syntax error, where the specified string is illegal or invalid.
property.description: Code used when an invalid string is specified

property.name: INVALID_MODIFICATION_ERR
property.remarks: This code is used when an attempt is made to modify the type of an object.
property.description: Code used when an attempt is made to change the type of an object

property.name: NAMESPACE_ERR
property.remarks: This code is used when an attempt is made to change or create an object in such a way that is invalid with regard to namespaces.
property.description: Code used when a change is made that is invalid in relation to namespaces

property.name: INVALID_ACCESS_ERR
property.remarks: This error code is used when an operation or parameter is called on an object that doesn't support it.
property.description: Code used when an operation is not supported by an object

property.name: code
property.description: Code corresponding to the type of DOMException thrown.

class.remarks: When some exceptional error situations arise during DOM manipulation, the method or object will raise an exception using the appropriate result code. Usually DOM methods will return specific error codes that correspond to the error involved and will not throw an exception. Therefore, this method will only be used in situations where the operation is impossible to recover from or perform. This usually arises when data is lost, the implementation is unstable, or for logical reasons.

It is equivilant to the Global object in ECMA-262.This permits a user to, for instance, create new documents, or determine if the DOM implementation supports some given feature. These are methods that do not belong in any DOM instance-related objects.

class.description: Represents an element in an HTML or XML document.

constructor.description: Represents an element in an HTML or XML document.

property.name: tagName
property.remarks:
Identifies the name of an element in a source document, including any namespace prefix. For example, in the following XML content, tagName value of the outer element (the ]]> element) returns "example1", while the inner element has a tagName value of "test:example2", even though the element name itself, without the namespace prefix is simply "example2".: 

                    
                    ]]>
property.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/aboutnodes.html
property.description: The tag name for this element

method.name: getAttribute

parameter.name: name
parameter.description: The name of the attribute to get the value for.

browser.description: Incorrectly returns the value "object" on the "style" attribute.
Returns internal style information on the "style" attribute.

method.example:
Using getAttribute

var node=document.getElementById('toolbar');
                    if (node.getAttribute('visible') == true) {
                    // Magic happens here
                    }

For more examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/attributes2.html
method.remarks:
This method retrieves one of the element's attributes that has the supplied name, and returns its value. If no attribute by that name exists as a child of the given element, an empty string is returned.

Its important to note that a copy of the attribute's value is returned, rather than a reference to the actual value. This means that you cannot modify the attribute value using this method. You need to use another method (like getAttributeNode or getAttributeNodeNS) that returns the Attr object itself to make changes.
method.description: Gets an attribute value by name.
method.return-description: Returns the value of the specified attribute.

method.name: getAttributeNode

parameter.name: name
parameter.description: The name of the attribute to get the Attr node object for.

method.example:
Using getAttributeNode

var attr=element.getAttributeNode("class");
                    if (! attr.specified) {
                    // This attribute is a default value
                    }

For more examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/attributes2.html
method.remarks: This method retrieves an attribute from an element, as an Attr object, rather than as a String. This is similar to the getAttribute method, except that method only returns the attribute's value. getAttributeNode lets you access a given attribute object without having to iterate over the attributes property.
method.description: Gets an attribute node by name
method.return-description: Returns the Attr object.

method.name: getAttributeNodeNS

parameter.name: namespaceURI
parameter.description: The namespace URI of the attribute node to get.

parameter.name: localName
parameter.description: Local name of the attribute node to get.

method.example:
Using getAttributeNodeNS

var attr=element.getAttributeNodeNS("http://mozref.com/NS/test", "name");
                    if (! attr.specified) {
                    // This attribute is a default value
                    }
method.remarks:
Similar to getAttributeNode and to getAttributeNS, this method retrieves an attribute's Attr object from the current Element by specifying both the attribute's namespace URI and local name.

Supplying the namespaceURI parameter with a null value is functionally equivilant to calling getAttributeNode.
method.description: Gets an attribute node by local name and namespace URI.
method.return-description: Returns the Attr node object.

method.name: getAttributeNS

parameter.name: namespaceURI
parameter.description: The namespace URI of the attribute to get.

parameter.name: localName
parameter.description: The local name of the attribute to get.

method.example:
Using getAttributeNS

/* Given the source XML:
                    
                    
                    
                    */
                    var value=element.getAttributeNS("http://mozref.com/NS/test", "name");
method.remarks:
Similar to getAttribute, this method retrieves one of the element's attributes. In this instance though, both the namespace URI and local name of the attribute can be used to select the appropriate attribute.

Supplying the namespaceURI parameter with a null value is functionally equivilant to calling getAttribute.
method.description: Gets an attribute value by local name and namespace URI
method.return-description: Returns the value of the attribute.

method.name: getElementsByTagName

parameter.name: name
parameter.description: Tag name of the element(s) to retrieve. (Use "*" as a wild card to return all tags.)

browser.description: Does not work in IE 5.0 on Windows.

method.example:
Using getElementsByTagName

var ctxt=document.getElementById("sidebar-div");
                    for ( var link in ctxt.getElementsByTagName("a") ) {
                    // Do something with this link
                    }

For additional examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/basics.html
method.remarks:
When trying to retrieve elements from the DOM, you do not often know the ID of the elements in question, but you know the type of element they are. Therefore, the Document object provides the getElementsByTagName method for searching the DOM and returning a list of elements matching the supplied tag name.

However, there may be many instances of that same XML element that are not relevant. Therefore, this same method is made available on all Element nodes, permitting you to search from the potentially much smaller subset of elements that are descendents of the current element.
method.description: Returns a NodeList array of all Element nodes descending from the specified Element.
method.return-description: Returns a NodeList array of all Element nodes descending from the specified Element.

method.name: getElementsByTagNameNS

parameter.name: namespaceURI
parameter.description: Namespace URI of the elements to get. (Use "*" as a wild card.)

parameter.name: localName
parameter.description: The local name of the elements to get. (Use "*" as a wild card to return all tag names.)

method.example:
Using getElementsByTagNameNS

var ctxt=document.getElementById("toolbar-menubar");
                    var menuitems=ctxt.getElementsByTagNameNS(
                    "http://www.mozilla.org/keymaster/gatekeeper/there.is.only.xul",
                    "menuitem");
                    for ( var menuitem in menuitems ) {
                    // Do something with this menu item
                    }
method.remarks:
Similar to getElementsByTagName, this method retrieves an element's descendent Element objects that match the supplied namespace URI and local name.

Supplying the namespaceURI parameter with a null value is functionally equivilant to calling getElementsByTagName.
method.description: Gets a list of all descendent elements by local tag name and namespace URI
method.return-description: Returns a NodeList of ehe Element objects that descend from the specified Element and have the specified name and namespace URI.

method.name: hasAttribute

parameter.name: name
parameter.description: Name of the attribute to check.

method.example:
Using hasAttribute

if (!element.hasAttribute("id")) {
                    element.setAttribute("id", "newvalue");
                    }

For more examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/attributes3.html
method.remarks: Use this method to verify that an attribute exists on an Element before retrieving that attribute.
method.description: Determines if the given attribute exists on this element.
method.return-description: Returns true if the specified attribute exists on the element.

method.name: hasAttributeNS

parameter.name: namespaceURI
parameter.description: Namespace URI of the attribute to check.

parameter.name: localName
parameter.description: Local name of the attribute to check.

method.example:
Using hasAttributeNS

/* Given the source XML:
                    
                    
                    
                    */
                    if (!element.hasAttributeNS("http://mozref.com/NS/test", "name")) {
                    element.setAttributeNS("http://mozref.com/NS/test", "name", "newvalue");
                    }
method.remarks: Similar to hasAttribute, this method returns a boolean value indicating an attribute exists on the given element. In this instance, the hasAttributeNS method takes an extra parameter specifying the namespace URI for the attribute, enabling you to check for attributes that have a namespace associated with them.
method.description: Determines if the given attribute local name and namespace URI exists on this element
method.return-description: Returns true if the element has the specified attribute.

method.name: removeAttribute

parameter.name: name
parameter.description: Name of the attribute to remove.

exception.description: Raises a NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR error if the node is read-only.

method.example:
Using removeAttribute

if (element.hasAttribute("id")) {
                    element.removeAttribute("id");
                    }

For more examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/attributes2.html
method.remarks: Removes the specified attribute from the element. If the attribute has a defined default value, it will be set to that default value.
method.description: Removes an attribute by name

method.name: removeAttributeNode

parameter.name: oldAttr
parameter.description: Node to remove from the attribute.

exception.description: Raises a NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR error if the node is read-only. Raises a NOT_FOUND_ERR error if oldAttr object is not an attribute of this element.

browser.description: Minimal support in IE 6.0 (Windows) and IE 5 (Mac).

method.remarks: Removes an attribute from an element. If the attribute has a defined default value, the new attribute node value will immediately be set to that.
method.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/attributes2.html
method.description: Removes the specified attribute node
method.return-description: Returns the Attr node that has been removed.

method.name: removeAttributeNS

exception.description: Raises a NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR error if the node is read-only.

method.remarks: This method removes an attribute from an Element based on the attribute's local name and namespace URI. If this attribute has a default value, a new attribute with the default value will immediately replace it, with the same local name, namespace URI and namespace prefix as the original attribute.
method.description: Removes an attribute by local name and namespace URI

method.name: setAttribute

parameter.name: name
parameter.description: Name of the attribute to set.

parameter.name: value
parameter.description: String value of the attribute to set.

exception.description: Raises an INVALID_CHARACTER_ERR error if the supplied name contains an invalid character.
Raises a NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR error if the node is read-only.

browser.description: IE removes event attributes when you try to set style attributes.

method.example:
Using setAttribute

var node=document.getElementById('address-list');
                    document.setAttribute('ref', 'urn:root');
                    document.setAttribute('datasources', 'http://mozref.com/reference/objects.rdf');

For more examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/attributes2.html
method.remarks: Sets either a new attribute value or updates an existing attribute value. This method can only set values as text strings, not HTML. Entities will not be parsed. To assign values containing entities to an attribute, use setAttributeNode or setAttributeNodeNS.
method.description: Adds a new attribute.

method.name: setAttributeNode

parameter.name: newAttr
parameter.description: Attr node of the attribute to set.

exception.description: Raises a WRONG_DOCUMENT_ERR error if the supplied newAttr was created from a different document.
Raises a NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR error if the node is read-only.
Raises an INUSE_ATTRIBUTE_ERR error if the supplied newAttr is already bound to another Element object.

browser.description: Safari will create the attribute, but you will have to use nodeValue to set its value.

method.example:
Using setAttributeNode

var attr=node1.getAttributeNode("class");
                    node1.removeAttribute("class");
                    node2.setAttributeNode(attr);

For more examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/attributes3.html
method.remarks:
This method adds the specified Attr object as an attribute to the current element. You may specifiy actual DOM nodes instead of specifying separate arguments for the attribute name and value.

If the element already has the attribute, setAttribute will replace the node and return the old attribute node. Returns null, otherwise.
method.description: Adds the given attribute node
method.return-description: Returns the Attr node that the newAttr node replaced.

method.name: setAttributeNodeNS

parameter.name: newAttr
parameter.description: Attr node of the attribute to set, including the namespace information.

exception.description: Raises a WRONG_DOCUMENT_ERR error if the supplied newAttr was created from a different document.
Raises a NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR error if the node is read-only.
Raises an INUSE_ATTRIBUTE_ERR error if the supplied newAttr is already bound to another Element object.

method.remarks:
Like it's non-namespace aware counterpart setAttributeNode, this method sets or replaces an attribute in an Element node by supplying the actual Attr node that is to be bound to the object. Unlike setAttributeNode, this method is aware of, and can set, the attribute using the localName and namespaceURI.

If an attribute already exists in this Element with the supplied attribute name properties, then it is replaced, and the old attribute is returned. Otherwise, null is returned.
method.description: Sets an attribute value with the given node's name and namespace URI.
method.return-description: Returns the Attr node that the newAttr node replaced.

method.name: setAttributeNS

parameter.name: namespaceURI
parameter.description: Namespace URI of the attribute to set.

parameter.name: qualifiedName
parameter.description: Fully qualified name of the attribute to set.

parameter.name: value
parameter.description: String value of the attribute to set.

exception.description: Raises an INVALID_CHARACTER_ERR error if the supplied name contains an invalid character.
Raises a NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR error if the node is read-only.

Raises a NAMESPACE_ERR error if the qualifiedName is invalid, if the qualifiedName contains a namespace prefix yet no namespaceURI is supplied, if the namespace prefix is "xml" or "xmlns" and has a namespaceURI that does not match the prefix.

method.example:
Using setAttributeNS

node.setAttributeNS(
                    "http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#",
                    "rdf:about",
                    "urn:root"
                    );
method.remarks:
This method, similar to the setAttribute method, sets a new attribute value. If the attribute already exists, it's value is set to the one supplied to this method. This version of the method however takes both a qualified name and namespace URI when setting the attribute. This permits the creation of attributes defined with namespaces.

Like setAttribute, this method accepts only plain string values, and as such cannot be used for defining entity references within strings. Any entity reference will be escaped prior to being set with the attribute. If you would like to assign values containing entities to an attribute, please see setAttributeNode or setAttributeNodeNS.
method.description: Adds a new attribute with a namespace URI

class.remarks:
One of the most critical objects within the DOM, the Element object represents an individual element within an XML or HTML document. Due to the capabilities of XML elements, this object provides several methods for handling attributes.

The attribute manipulation methods can be divided into three different groups: plain methods, node-oriented methods, and namespace-aware methods. The first category is the simplest, and permits both the attribute name and value to be supplied to the method, thus creating an Attr under the covers. The second category enables a user to create an Attr themselves, and merely to attach it to the Element object. The final category is similar to the first, except an extra argument can be supplied which allows you to create an attribute with an XML namespace.

Many of the capabilities of this object is inherited from Node, since they share many similarities. Therefore, this object exposes methods to get at all the available attributes (since it inherits the attributes property), individual attribute values, or individual Attr objects.

class.remarks:
This object represents an entity from a Document Type Declaration (DTD). Entities are declarations of abbreviated text or other nodes within an XML document. These can then be inserted at various places in an XML document with EntityReference objects.

While the entity name is stored in the Node.nodeName property, the rest of the entity's data (the actual content of the entity) is stored as children of this object (in the Node.childNodes property). The Node.parentNode for Entity nodes will always be null.

Entity objects are read-only and cannot be modified once they are added to the document or after a document is loaded. If you need to change an entity's contents you should create a new one and change all the EntityReference nodes that referred to the old entity to refer to the new one instead.

class.description: Represents an Entity Reference in a document.

constructor.description: Represents an Entity Reference in a document.

class.remarks: This object represents an entity reference that refers to an Entity within the document. Entity references are nodes within the DOM tree that essentially copies the nodes contained in an entity to as many locations within the document as is needed. As with Entity objects, the children nodes of entity references are read-only.

class.remarks:
Whenever some event occurs with the DOM, different event handlers are given the choice of intercepting and doing something with it. The Event object is used to provide context that each event handler can use to get information about the event, like the originating element, what stage the event is currently in within the event system, and so forth.

More specific events, that provide additional context information based on the type of event. For instance, the MouseEvent object, which inherits from Event, supplies additional properties supplying information such as the MouseEvent.button, MouseEvent.screenX and MouseEvent.screenY for where the current mouse event took place.

Due to this, the properties and methods supported by the Event object are rather minimal, and supply the basic set of functionality required for all types of events.

property.name: onfocus
property.description: Fires when the element receives focus.

property.name: onhelp
property.description: Fires when a user presses the F1 key to activate help.

property.name: onkeydown
property.description: Fires when a user presses down on a key while the element has focus.

property.name: onkeypress
property.description: Fires when a user presses a key or holds down the key while the element has focus.

property.name: onkeyup
property.description: Fires when a user releases a key while the element has focus.

property.name: onlosecapture
property.description: Fires when the element loses mouse capture.

property.name: onmousedown
property.description: Fires when a user clicks down on the mouse button while the element has focus.

property.name: onmouseenter
property.description: Fires when the mouse pointer enters the element.
property.remarks: Differs from onmouseover in that onmouseenter does not bubble and is not cancelable.

property.name: onmouseleave
property.description: Fires when the mouse pointer leaves the element.
property.remarks: Differs from onmouseout in that onmouseleave does not bubble and is not cancelable.

property.name: onmousemove
property.description: Fires when the mouse moves while the pointer over the element.

property.name: onmouseout
property.description: Fires when the mouse pointer moves off of the element.

property.name: onmouseover
property.description: Fires when the mouse pointer moves over the element.

property.name: onmouseup
property.description: Fires when the user releases the mouse button while the element has focus.

property.name: onpaste
property.description: Fires when the clipboard contents are pasted onto the element.

property.description: Fires when one of the properties of the element changes.

method.name: applyElement

parameter.name: newElement
parameter.description: Tag name of the element to add.

parameter.name: where
parameter.description: Specifies where to add the new element (i.e. either as a parent or child of the current element). Specify a value of "outside" (or omit) to add the new element as a parent to the current element. Otherwise the new element becomes the first child of the current element and any existing children of the current element then become direct children of the new element.

method.description: Adds a new element to the current element either as a child or parent of the current element.
method.return-description: Returns a new HTMLElement with the specified node structure.

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/movingnodes.html

method.description: Returns a TextRectangle that marks the top, bottom, left, and right boundaries (in pixels) of the content of the element.
method.return-description: Returns the node of the specified attribute.

method.name: getClientRects
method.description: Returns a collection of all of the TextRectangle objects contained by the element.
method.return-description: Returns a collection of all of the TextRectangle objects contained by the element.

method.name: getElementsByTagName

parameter.name: tagname
parameter.description: Tag name of the elements to return. Specify "*" to return all tags.

browser.description: Does not work in IE 5.0 on Windows.

method.example:
Using getElementsByTagName

// Assume there is only one  in the document
                    var body=document.getElementsByTagName("body").item(0);
                    var paragraphs=body.getElementsByTagName("p");

For additional examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/basics.html
method.remarks: This method returns a list of elements in the document that have the specified tagName. The returned NodeList is sorted in the order the elements were found during a depth-first preorder traversal through the node tree.
method.description: Returns an array of Element nodes with the specified tag name.
method.return-description: Returns an array of Element nodes with the specified tag name.

parameter.name: propertyName
parameter.description: Name of the property/attribute.

method.description: Returns the property expression specified by propertyName.
method.return-description: Returns the property expression specified by propertyName.

method.name: hasAttribute

parameter.name: name
parameter.description: Name of the attribute to check.

method.example:
Using hasAttribute

if (!element.hasAttribute("id")) {
                    element.setAttribute("id", "newvalue");
                    }

For more examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/attributes3.html
method.remarks: Use this method to verify that an attribute exists on an Element before retrieving that attribute.
method.description: Determines if the given attribute exists on this element.
method.return-description: Returns true if the specified attribute exists on the element.

method.name: hasAttributes
method.example:
Using hasAttributes

var obj=document.Document.getElementById('EmailAddress');
                    if (obj.hasAttributes()) {
                    window.alert("The node " + obj.Node.nodeName + " has attributes");
                    }

For more examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/attributes3.html
method.remarks: Returns true if this node is an Element and has any attributes. Returns false if there are none. Equivilant to checking node.attributes.NamedNodeMap.length > 0.
method.description: Returns true if the node is an element node with attributes.
method.return-description: Returns true if the node is an element node with attributes.

method.name: hasChildNodes
method.example:
Using hasChildNodes

var obj=document.Document.getElementById('EmailAddress');
                    if (obj.hasChildNodes()) {
                    window.alert("The node " + obj.Node.nodeName + " has children");
                    }
method.remarks: Returns true if this node has any child nodes. Returns false if there are none. Equivilant to checking node.childNodes.NodeList.length > 0.
method.description: Returns true if the node has child nodes.
method.return-description: Returns true if the node has child nodes.

method.name: insertAdjacentElement

parameter.name: where
parameter.description: Specifies where to insert the element. Valid values are beforeBegin, afterBegin, beforeEnd, and afterEnd.

parameter.name: element
parameter.description: Element to insert.

method.description: Inserts the specified Element object adjacent to this element.

parameter.name: where
parameter.description: Specifies where to insert the element. Valid values are beforeBegin, afterBegin, beforeEnd, and afterEnd.

method.description: Inserts the specified string of HTML text adjacent to this element. Parsed as HTML.

parameter.name: where

method.name: isSupported

parameter.name: feature
parameter.description: Name of the feature.

parameter.name: version
parameter.description: Version of the feature.

method.remarks: Tests whether a node supports the specified feature. Similar to the DOMImplementation.hasFeature method and takes the same feature names. If version is null, returns true if any version of the feature is supported.
method.description: Returns true if the specified feature and version are supported.
method.return-description: Returns true if the specified feature and version are supported.

parameter.name: source
parameter.description: Source that supplies the attributes.

parameter.description: If true, specifies that the id of the current element should be preserved.

method.description: Merges the attributes from the source element to the current element.

method.name: normalize

browser.description: May crash IE 6.0.

method.remarks:
Normalizes any Text nodes contained under this node and all of its children. Merges any adjacent Text nodes into one object, so that the nodes reflect how they would be structured if this XML document were freshly loaded.

Normalize() is useful for manipulating the text content of nodes for editing. Instead of worrying about altering existing Text nodes, you can simply add new nodes and perform the normalize when you finish your updates.
method.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/splittext.html
method.description: Merges text nodes adjacent to the element to create a normalized DOM.

method.name: releaseCapture
method.description: Stops the mouse from capturing events on the element.

method.name: removeAttribute

parameter.name: name
parameter.description: Name of the attribute to remove.

exception.description: Raises a NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR error if the node is read-only.

browser.description: IE does not remove events.

method.example:
Using removeAttribute

if (element.hasAttribute("id")) {
                    element.removeAttribute("id");
                    }

For more examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/attributes2.html
method.remarks: Removes the specified attribute from the element. If the attribute has a defined default value, it will be set to that default value.
method.description: Removes an attribute by name

method.name: removeAttributeNode

parameter.name: oldAttr
parameter.description: Node to remove from the attribute.

exception.description: Raises a NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR error if the node is read-only. Raises a NOT_FOUND_ERR error if oldAttr object is not an attribute of this element.

browser.description: Minimal support in IE 6.0 (Windows) and IE 5 (Mac).

method.remarks: Removes an attribute from an element. If the attribute has a defined default value, the new attribute node value will immediately be set to that.
method.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/attributes2.html
method.description: Removes the specified attribute node
method.return-description: Returns the Attr node that has been removed.

method.name: removeBehavior

parameter.name: id
parameter.description: id of the behavior to remove.

method.remarks: Removes the behavior specified by id from the element.
method.description: Removes the specified attribute node
method.return-description: Returns returns true if the behavior is successfully removed.

method.name: removeChild

parameter.name: oldChild
parameter.description: Child node to remove.

exception.description: Raises a NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR if the node is read-only.
Raises a NOT_FOUND_ERR if the supplied node is not a child of this one.

method.example:
Using removeChild

var obj=document.Document.getElementById('EmailAddress');
                    try {
                    var oldChild=obj.removeChild(obj.Node.firstChild);
                    } catch DOMException {
                    // Error handling
                    };

For more examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/movingnodes.html
method.remarks: Removes and returns the specified child node from the list of this node's children.
method.description: Removes the specified child node from the element and returns the node.
method.return-description: Removes the specified child node from the element and returns the node.

method.name: removeEventListener

parameter.name: type
parameter.description: Type of event.

parameter.name: listener
parameter.description: Event listener to be removed.

parameter.name: useCapture
parameter.description: Specify "true" to remove a capturing event listener. Specify "false" to remove all other types of event listeners.

method.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/js/events/registration.html
method.description: Removes an event listener from an event target.

parameter.name: propertyName

method.name: replaceAdjacentText

parameter.name: where
parameter.description: Specifies where to insert the element. Valid values are beforeBegin, afterBegin, beforeEnd, and afterEnd.

parameter.name: text
parameter.description: Text to replace the current text with.

method.description: Replaces the current text adjacent to the element with the specified text.

method.name: replaceChild

parameter.name: newChild
parameter.description: Node to replace the oldChild node with.

parameter.name: oldChild
parameter.description: Node to be replaced.

exception.description: Raises a HIERARCHY_REQUEST_ERR error if either the node being inserted is one of this node's ancestors, or if the current node does not allow this type of node as a child.
Raises a WRONG_DOCUMENT_ERR error if the newChild node was not created within the current document.
Raises a NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR if this node is read-only or if the parent of the new node is read-only.
Raises a NOT_FOUND_ERR if the supplied oldChild node is not a child of this one.

method.example:
Using replaceChild

var obj=document.Document.getElementById('EmailAddress');
                    var newElement=document.Document.createElement('label');
                    try {
                    var oldChild=obj.replaceChild(newElement, obj.Node.lastChild);
                    } catch DOMException {
                    // Error handling
                    };

For more examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/movingnodes.html
method.remarks:
This method simplifies the process of calling removeChild and then insertBefore, so that you do not have to worry if this node is the first or last child.

The new child node is removed if it already exists somewhere else in the DOM tree. If the new child is a DocumentFragment node, the oldChild node is replaced by all of the nodes within the DocumentFragment, in the same order.
method.description: Removes the specified child node, replaces it with another node, and returns the removed node.
method.return-description: Returns the replaced oldChild node.

method.name: replaceNode

parameter.name: newNode
parameter.description: Node to replace the current node with.

method.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/movingnodes.html
method.description: Replaces the current node with the node specified in newNode.

method.name: scrollIntoView

parameter.name: alignToTop
parameter.description: If true, specifies that the top of the element will be scrolled to align with the top of the window. Default is true.

method.remarks: Use the scrollIntoView method to visually direct users to a specific part of a web page, without forcing the users to scroll the page themselves. (e.g. Scrolling down to the "total" of a long shopping cart page.)
method.description: Immediately scrolls the element into the viewable portion of the web page.

method.name: setActive
method.description: Sets this element as "active" without giving focus to the element.

method.name: setAttribute

parameter.name: name
parameter.description: Name of the attribute to set.

parameter.name: value
parameter.description: String value of the attribute to set.

exception.description: Raises an INVALID_CHARACTER_ERR error if the supplied name contains an invalid character.
Raises a NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR error if the node is read-only.

browser.description: IE removes event attributes when you try to set style attributes.

method.example:
Using setAttribute

var node=document.getElementById('address-list');
                    document.setAttribute('ref', 'urn:root');
                    document.setAttribute('datasources', 'http://mozref.com/reference/objects.rdf');

For more examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/attributes2.html
method.remarks: Sets either a new attribute value or updates an existing attribute value. This method can only set values as text strings, not HTML. Entities will not be parsed. To assign values containing entities to an attribute, use setAttributeNode.
method.description: Adds a new attribute.

method.name: setAttributeNode

parameter.name: newAttr
parameter.description: Attr node of the attribute to set.

exception.description: Raises a WRONG_DOCUMENT_ERR error if the supplied newAttr was created from a different document.
Raises a NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR error if the node is read-only.
Raises an INUSE_ATTRIBUTE_ERR error if the supplied newAttr is already bound to another Element object.

browser.description: Safari will create the attribute, but you will have to use nodeValue to set its value.

method.example:
Using setAttributeNode

var attr=node1.getAttributeNode("class");
                    node1.removeAttribute("class");
                    node2.setAttributeNode(attr);

For more examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/attributes3.html
method.remarks:
This method adds the specified Attr object as an attribute to the current element. You may specifiy actual DOM nodes instead of specifying separate arguments for the attribute name and value.

If the element already has the attribute, setAttribute will replace the node and return the old attribute node. Returns null, otherwise.
method.description: Adds the given attribute node
method.return-description: Returns the Attr node that the newAttr node replaced.

method.name: setCapture

parameter.name: containerCapture
parameter.description: If true, specifies that events that originate in the container will be captured by the container.

method.remarks: Once set, routes all mouse events to this element.
method.description: Sets mouse capture to the element.
