value.description: Select an event that is not on this list.

value.name: onabort
value.description: Fires when the loading of the element is cancelled before it finishes loading.

value.name: onactivate
value.description: Fires when the element becomes active.

value.name: onafterprint
value.description: Fires immediately after a user prints or print previews a document.

value.name: onafterupdate
value.description: Fires when the data from a datasource is successfully updated for a databound object.

value.name: onbeforeactivate
value.description: Fires immediately before the element becomes active.

value.name: onbeforecopy
value.description: Fires immediately before the selection is copied to the clipboard.

value.name: onbeforecut
value.description: Fires immediately before the selection is cut to the clipboard.

value.name: onbeforedeactivate
value.description: Fires immediately before the element stops being the active element.

value.name: onbeforeeditfocus
value.description: Fires immediately before the element receives focus prior to being edited.

value.name: onbeforepaste
value.description: Fires immediately before the selection is pasted from the clipboard to the element.

value.name: onbeforeprint
value.description: Fires immediately before a user prints or print previews a document.

value.name: onbeforeunload
value.description: Fires immediately before a document is unloaded.

value.name: onbeforeupdate
value.description: Fires immediately before the data from a datasource is updated for a databound object.

value.name: onblur
value.description: Fires when the element loses focus.

value.name: onbounce
value.description: Fires immediately before the scrolling contents of an element reach the far side of the window.

value.name: oncellchange
value.description: Fires when the data from the datasource changes.

value.name: onchange
value.description: Fires when the value of the element changes.

value.name: onclick
value.description: Fires when the element is clicked.

value.name: oncontextmenu
value.description: Fires when the element is right-clicked and the context menu opens.

value.name: oncontrolselect
value.description: Fires immediately before the element is selected.

value.name: oncopy
value.description: Fires when the element is copied to the clipboard.

value.name: oncut
value.description: Fires when the element is cut to the clipboard.

value.name: ondataavailable
value.description: Fires when data becomes available from an asyncrhonous data source.

value.name: ondatasetchanged
value.description: Fires when data in a dataset changes.

value.name: ondatasetcomplete
value.description: Fires when a dataset finishes loading.

value.name: ondblclick
value.description: Fires when the element is double-clicked.

value.name: ondeactivate
value.description: Fires when the active element becomes inactive.

value.name: ondrag
value.description: Fires when the element is dragged.

value.name: ondragend
value.description: Fires when the element is released from being dragged.

value.name: ondragenter
value.description: Fires when the element has another object dragged onto it that can be dropped on the element.

value.name: ondragleave
value.description: Fires when an element has an object dragged out of it that could be dropped onto the element.

value.name: ondragover
value.description: Fires when an element has an object dragged over it that could be dropped onto the element.

value.name: ondragstart
value.description: Fires immediately before an element is dragged.

value.name: ondrop
value.description: Fires when an object is dropped onto the element.

value.name: onerror
value.description: Fires when an error occurs with the object associated with the element.

value.name: onerrorupdate
value.description: Fires when an error occurs while updating the datasource of a databound object.

value.name: onfilterchange
value.description: Fires when the CSS Filter of an element changes or finishes transitioning.

value.name: onfinish
value.description: Fires when looping for the element completes.

value.name: onfocus
value.description: Fires when the element receives focus.

value.name: onfocusin
value.description: Fires immediately before an element receives focus.

value.name: onfocusout
value.description: Fires immediately after focus moves from the element to another element.

value.name: onhelp
value.description: Fires when a user presses the F1 key to activate help.

value.description: Fires when a user presses down on a key while the element has focus.

value.name: onkeypress
value.description: Fires when a user presses a key or holds down the key while the element has focus.

value.name: onkeyup
value.description: Fires when a user releases a key while the element has focus.

value.name: onlayoutcomplete
value.description: Fires when Print or Print Preview finishes laying out the content in a LayoutRect with the source data.

value.name: onload
value.description: Fires when the content of the element finishes loading.

value.name: onlosecapture
value.description: Fires when the element loses mouse capture.

value.name: onmousedown
value.description: Fires when a user clicks down on the mouse button while the element has focus.

value.name: onmouseenter
value.description: Fires when the mouse pointer enters the element.

value.name: onmouseleave
value.description: Fires when the mouse pointer leaves the element.

value.name: onmousemove
value.description: Fires when the mouse moves while the pointer over the element.

value.name: onmouseout
value.description: Fires when the mouse pointer moves off of the element.

value.name: onmouseover
value.description: Fires when the mouse pointer moves over the element.

value.description: Fires when the user releases the mouse button while the element has focus.

value.description: Fires when the user rotates the mouse wheel while the element has focus.

value.description: Fires when the element stops moving.

value.description: Fires immediately before the element moves.

class.description: Collection of nodes accessible by name or position.

constructor.description: Collection of nodes accessible by name or position.

property.name: length
property.remarks: Returns the number of nodes stored within this node map. This can be used in conjunction with the <method>item</method> method for enumerating through the list of nodes.
property.description: Number of nodes in this node map.

method.name: getNamedItem

parameter.name: name
parameter.description: Name of the node.

method.example:
Using getNamedItem

var element=document.Document.getElementById('linkElement');
                    var linkTarget=element.Node.attributes.getNamedItem('href');
method.remarks:
Retrieves a node from the object referenced by the given name. Like most methods within this object, the name of each node contained within a node map is derived from that node's Node.nodeName property.

This is the DOM1-compatible method for retrieving items from a node map and as such does not understand XML Namespaces. If you need to manipulate node maps containing namespaces, use this method's companion function getNamedItemNS.
method.description: Returns the specified node.
method.return-description: Returns the specified node.

method.name: getNamedItemNS

parameter.name: namespaceURI
parameter.description: Namespace URI of the node to retrieve.

parameter.name: localName
parameter.description: Local name of the node to retrieve.

method.example:
Using getNamedItemNS

var element=document.Document.getElementById('menubar');
                    var xulNS='http://www.mozilla.org/keymaster/gatekeeper/there.is.only.xul';
                    var attr=element.Node.attributes.getNamedItemNS(xulNS, 'datasources');
method.remarks:
Retrieves a node from the object referenced by the given name and XML namespace URI. Like most methods within this object, the name of each node contained within a node map is derived from that node's Node.nodeName property. This method breaks the node's name out into it's two-part Namespace-enabled node name for elements that support it, namely Attr and Element.

This is the DOM2 method for retrieving items from a node map, though it isn't necessary for retrieving nodes that either don't use namespaces or for nodes that don't understand the concept of namespace URIs, like Text. If you need to retrieve nodes without namespaces, use this method's companion function getNamedItem.
method.description: Returns the node identified by the given name and XML namespace URI.
method.return-description: Returns the node identified by the given name and XML namespace URI.

method.name: item

parameter.name: index
parameter.description: Index number to retrieve.

method.example:
Using item

if (nodeMap.length > 0) {
                    for (var idx=0; idx < nodeMap.length; idx++) {
                    var node=nodeMap.item(idx);
                    // Do something with this node
                    }
                    }

For more examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/item.html
method.remarks: Returns the node contained within this object at the given index number. It is important to note that node maps do not keep it's nodes in any specific order. As such, the item method and length property are only provided to enumerate through a map's contents.
method.description: Returns the node at the specified index number.
method.return-description: Returns the node at the specified index number.

method.name: removeNamedItem

parameter.name: name
parameter.description: Name of the node to remove from the map

exception.description: Raises a NOT_FOUND_ERR error if the given name is not found in this map.
Raises a NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR error if this node map object is read-only.

method.remarks:
Removes a node from the map matching the given name. This method returns the indicated node after it has been removed.

If this map represents the Node.attributes bound to an Element and the XML document has a default attribute defined for the attribute being removed, then a new entry for this attribute's default value will immediately re-appear in this node map.

This is the DOM1-compatible method for removing items from a node map and as such does not understand XML Namespaces. If you need to manipulate node maps containing namespaces, use this method's companion function removeNamedItemNS.
method.description: Removes the specified node from the map.
method.return-description: Returns the removed node.

method.name: removeNamedItemNS

parameter.name: namespaceURI
parameter.description: Namespace URI of the node to remove.

parameter.name: localName
parameter.description: Local name of the node to remove.

exception.description: Raises a NOT_FOUND_ERR error if the given name is not found in this map.
Raises a NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR error if this node map object is read-only.

method.remarks: Removes a node from the map matching the given name. This method is identical in operation to the removeNamedItem method in this object, with the exception that this method is aware of XML Namespaces. If you are removing a node from the map that is defined with an XML namespace, then you should be using this method.
method.description: Remove the node identified by the given name and XML namespace URI.
method.return-description: Returns the removed node.

method.name: setNamedItem

parameter.name: arg
parameter.description: Node to add to the map.

exception.description: Raises a WRONG_DOCUMENT_ERR error if the supplied node was created in a different document from the current map object.
Raises a NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR error if this node is read-only.
Raises an INUSE_ATTRIBUTE_ERR error if the supplied node is an Attr object that is already bound to an Element.

method.remarks:
Adds the given node to the node map. Like most methods within this object, the name of each node contained within a node map is derived from that node's Node.nodeName property. If an entry already exists in the map with the name of the new node being added, the old node is removed and is subsequently returned from this method call. In the event that there is no other node with the same name however, then null is returned.

Because you don't have the capability of setting explicit names for a node you add to a map, it is possible for name conflicts when two nodes have the same name. Since certain types of DOM Nodes always return the same name (see Node.nodeName), as in Text nodes for instance, then it is only possible to store one node per node type in a named map.

This is the DOM1-compatible method for setting items in a node map and as such does not understand XML Namespaces. If you need to manipulate node maps containing namespaces, use this method's companion function setNamedItemNS.
method.description: Add the supplied node to the map.
method.return-description: Returns the replaced node.

method.name: setNamedItemNS

parameter.name: arg
parameter.description: Node to add to the map.

exception.description: Raises a WRONG_DOCUMENT_ERR error if the supplied node was created in a different document from the current map object.
Raises a NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR error if this node is read-only.
Raises an INUSE_ATTRIBUTE_ERR error if the supplied node is an Attr object that is already bound to an Element.

method.remarks: Adds the given node to the node map. This method is identical in operation to the setNamedItem method in this object, with the exception that this method is aware of XML Namespaces. If you are adding a node to the map that is defined with an XML namespace, then you should be using this method.
method.description: Add the supplied node defined with XML namespaces to the map
method.return-description: Returns the replaced node.

class.remarks:
This object is used to represent collections of nodes that can be accessed by name. NamedNodeMap is similar to the NodeList object, except its contents are accessed by the value of a node's Node.nodeName property, rather than by a numeric index. This is equivilant in concept to a "hash" or "associative array" in other languages.

This object is mainly used in the Node object to represent XML Node.attributes, though is also used in a few other places within the DOM.

class.description: Node in an HTML document tree.

constructor.description: Node in an HTML document tree.

property.name: attributes
property.remarks:
This property returns a listing of all the attributes bound to this Node. Since only Element nodes support attributes, most Node types will return a null value for this property.

NamedNodeMaps are essentially the DOM-equivilant of a hash. This property provides an alternative to the specific Element.getAttribute and Element.hasAttribute methods, which are usually used when you already know which attributes an element has. For those circumstances when you want to do some automatic discovery of attributes and their values, this property provides a convenient way to iterate through the element's attributes.

This property also has the added benefit of being usable across all nodes, not just Element nodes. Therefore no checking needs to be done ahead of time to verify if a node is an Element; rather you can iterate over the attributes list, since any element that has no attributes, or any other DOM node, will have a null value for this property.
property.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/attributes.html
property.description: Attributes for an element node.

property.name: childNodes
property.remarks:
The list of nodes that are immediate children of this node. The DOM is a heirarchial structure of Node objects. This property, combined with the parentNode properties provide the basics for defining this structure. Several convenience properties are provided for accessing some frequently-used children nodes, namely the firstChild and lastChild properties.

Since the NodeList class can be referenced as an array as well as its object-oriented interface, one can easily iterate through the contents of a node using standard JavaScript for loops. Because this property is read-only, you cannot alter the NodeList to effect this node's contents. Instead, the methods for addeding and removing nodes should be used, which will result in this being updated automatically.
property.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/children.html
property.description: Child nodes of the current node.

property.name: firstChild
property.remarks:
Returns the first child node from the list of the current node's children. If this node doesn't have any children, a null value will be returned.

This is functionally equivilant to invoking node.childNodes.NodeList.item(0), though this method is much more suscinct and doesn't require any error trapping if the child node doesn't exist.
property.description: First child node of the current node.
property.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/nodetree.html

property.name: lastChild
property.remarks:
Returns the last child node from the list of the current node's children. If this node doesn't have any children, a null value will be returned.

This is functionally equivilant to invoking node.childNodes.NodeList.item(node.childNodes.NodeList.length - 1), though this method is much more suscinct and doesn't require any error trapping if the child node doesn't exist.
property.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/nodetree.html
property.description: Last child node of the current node.

property.name: localName
property.description: Local part of an element or attribute name if it the node was defined with an XML Namespace.

property.name: namespaceURI
property.description: URI of the namespace for an element or attribute node if the node was defined with an XML Namespace.

property.name: nextSibling
property.remarks:
Returns the next node to the current one within the parent node's children. If this node is the last child within it's parent, then a null value will be returned.

When working with a node, it is often useful to be able to manipulate or search the nodes surrounding it. For instance, if given a node representing a label, you might want to find the text node immediately next to it. To help with this, the nextSibling property allows you to traverse to neighboring nodes in the DOM.
property.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/nodetree.html
property.description: Sibling node immediately after the current node.

property.name: nodeName
property.remarks:
This returns a name that represents this node's name. Depending on the type of object this is, this property will either return the name identifying this object; for instance, if this node is a Element or Attr object, then the tag or attribute name is returned. In other cases some place-holder text will be returned.

<property>nodeName</property> node-type valuesTypeleftValueleftAttr Attribute name CDATASection#cdata-sectionComment#commentDocument#documentDocumentFragment#document-fragmentDocumentType Document type name Element Tag name Entity Entity name EntityReference Name of entity referenced Notation Notation name ProcessingInstruction Target Text#text

If XML Namespaces were defined for this node and this node is a Element or Attr object (since these are the only node types that support the use of namespaces), this property returns the node name including the prefix and localName.

Returns an upper case tag name.
property.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/aboutnodes.html
property.description: Name of the node. Same as tag name for element nodes.

property.name: nodeType

browser.description: IE 5.0 on Windows does not assign nodeType attributes. Fixed in IE 5.5.

property.remarks:
This property returns an integer indicating what type of DOM Node this object represents.

Because the Node class is inherited by several other, more specific DOM objects, this property is a programmatic way of determining what an arbitrary node is, and therefore can tell the programmer how to interact with it. There are a series of constants defined in this object that can be used to refer to this property:

<property>nodeList</property> constant valuesValuerightConstantleft1ELEMENT_NODE2ATTRIBUTE_NODE3TEXT_NODE4CDATA_SECTION_NODE5ENTITY_REFERENCE_NODE6ENTITY_NODE7PROCESSING_INSTRUCTION_NODE8COMMENT_NODE9DOCUMENT_NODE10DOCUMENT_TYPE_NODE11DOCUMENT_FRAGMENT_NODE12NOTATION_NODE
property.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/aboutnodes.html
property.description: Type of node. See Remarks for valid values.

property.name: nodeValue
property.remarks: This represents the value of the node. Only Attr, CDATASection, Comment, ProcessingInstruction, and Text objects can contain a value in this property. For all other types of objects this property will return null, and setting it to a different value has no effect.
property.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/aboutnodes.html
property.description: Value of the current node.

property.name: ownerDocument
property.remarks: Refers to the Document object that this node exists in. Because a node must be created as a child of a Document, and since Node objects cannot be moved arbitrarily from one document to another (not without duplicating it), this is a way of referring to the parent document for a node so that document-wide method calls can be used for a node.
property.description: Document object that contains this node.
property.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/document.html

property.name: parentNode
property.remarks:
This property contains a reference to the parent node for the current node. Since the DOM is a heirarchial structure of nodes, the parentNode and childNodes properties tie the collection of nodes together.

Not all nodes can have parents however. Attr, Document, DocumentFragment, Entity and Notation objects and as such will contain a null value for this property. As well this property will be null for newly-created nodes that have yet to be added to a location within the DOM tree.
property.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/nodetree.html
property.description: Parent node of the current node.

property.name: prefix
property.description: Namespace prefix for an element or attribute node if the node was defined with an XML Namespace.

property.name: previousSibling
property.remarks: Returns the previous node to the current one within the parent node's children. If this node is the first child within it's parent, then a null value will be returned.
property.description: Sibling node immediately before the current node.
property.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/nodetree.html

method.name: appendChild

parameter.name: newChild
parameter.description: Node to add to the current element as a child.

exception.description: Raises a HIERARCHY_REQUEST_ERR error if either the supplied node is one of this node's ancestors, or if the current node doesn't allow the given type of node as a child.
Raises a WRONG_DOCUMENT_ERR error if the supplied node doesn't exist within this node's document.
Raises a NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR error if the node is read-only.

browser.description: Appending an "option" element to a "select" element may crash IE 5.0 on Windows.

method.example:
Using appendChild

var newElement=document.Document.createElement('label');
                    newElement.Element.setAttribute('value', 'Username:');
                    var usernameText=document.Document.getElementById('username');
                    usernameText.appendChild(newElement);

For more examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/movingnodes.html
method.remarks:
Add the provided node at the end of this node's children. The newly added node is returned when the operation is completed. There are a few interesting caveats with this method.

If the node supplied to this method already exists somewhere in the DOM tree, then it is first removed before being appended. As well, if the value supplied to this method is a DocumentFragment, then the entire contents of the fragment are moved to the end of this node's children.
method.description: Appends a node to the childNodes array for the node.
method.return-description: Returns the removed node, if applicable.

method.name: cloneNode

parameter.name: deep
parameter.description: If true, clone the child nodes, also.

browser.description: On a Mac, IE 5.0 does not clone the event handlers for an element.

method.example:
Using cloneNode

var myObject=document.Document.getElementById('EmailAddress');
                    var newObject=myObject.cloneNode(true);
                    newObject.id='ClonedEmailAddress';
                    myObject.parentNode.insertBefore(newObject, myObject);

For more examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/movingnodes.html
method.remarks:
Because a Node can only exist in one location in the DOM tree at a time, it is necessary to create and insert a new node even if you want a simple copy of an element or attribute, or any other kind of DOM Node. This method, therefore, provides a facility for making an exact duplicate of a node, capable of being inserted into the DOM tree at another point.

Since Nodes are heirarchial, the argument to this method indicates whether or not you would like this node's children cloned as well. If you pass false into this method, then only the properties on the node you are cloning will be duplicated.

Once cloned, the new node will have no parent, requiring you to add it somewhere to the DOM tree yourself. When cloning a Element node, any properties defined by the XML processor, including attributes and their defaults, will be cloned. It's important to note, however, that the text contents of an Element are in fact Text nodes, and will not be cloned unless a deep clone is requested.

If you clone an Attr object explicitly, rather than simply cloning an Element, the Attr.specified property is set to true, regardless of whether or not the attribute you are cloning from was specified.

The requirements of having unique node IDs within a DOM tree still holds true, and as such any unique identifiers within the cloned nodes need to be changed before you insert them back into the DOM tree.
method.description: Creates a copy of either the node or the node and its children.
method.return-description: Returns the removed node, if applicable.

method.name: hasAttributes
method.example:
Using hasAttributes

var obj=document.Document.getElementById('EmailAddress');
                    if (obj.hasAttributes()) {
                    window.alert("The node " + obj.Node.nodeName + " has attributes");
                    }

For more examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/attributes3.html
method.remarks: Returns true if this node is an Element and has any attributes. Returns false if there are none. Equivilant to checking node.attributes.NamedNodeMap.length > 0.
method.description: Returns true if the node is an element node with attributes.
method.return-description: Returns true if the node is an element node with attributes.

method.name: hasChildNodes
method.example:
Using hasChildNodes

var obj=document.Document.getElementById('EmailAddress');
                    if (obj.hasChildNodes()) {
                    window.alert("The node " + obj.Node.nodeName + " has children");
                    }
method.remarks: Returns true if this node has any child nodes. Returns false if there are none. Equivilant to checking node.childNodes.NodeList.length > 0.
method.description: Returns true if the node has child nodes.
method.return-description: Returns true if the node has child nodes.

method.name: insertBefore

parameter.name: newChild
parameter.description: Child node to insert.

parameter.name: refChild
parameter.description: Sibling node for the new child.

exception.description: Raises a HIERARCHY_REQUEST_ERR error if either the supplied node is one of this node's ancestors, or if the current node doesn't allow the given type of node as a child.
Raises a WRONG_DOCUMENT_ERR error if the supplied node doesn't exist within this node's document.
Raises a NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR error if the node is read-only.
Raises a NOT_FOUND_ERR error if the supplied refChild node is not a child of this one.

method.example:
Using insertBefore

var obj=document.Document.getElementById('EmailAddress');
                    var newElement=document.Document.createElement('label');
                    var refElement=obj.Node.childNodes[3];
                    try {
                    obj.insertBefore(newElement, refElement);
                    } catch DOMException {
                    // Error handling
                    };

For more examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/movingnodes.html
method.remarks:
This method is used to insert a new child element at a very specific location in amongst multiple children. By specifying as the refChild parameter one of the element's children nodes, the new node will be inserted immediately prior to it.

If the node supplied to this method already exists somewhere in the DOM tree, then it is first removed before being inserted. As well, if the value supplied to this method is a DocumentFragment, then the entire contents of the fragment are inserted, in the same order, before the refChild reference node..
method.description: Inserts a node into the childNodes array for the node before the specified child node.
method.return-description: Returns any removed node.

method.name: isSupported

parameter.name: feature
parameter.description: Name of the feature.

parameter.name: version
parameter.description: Version of the feature.

method.remarks: Tests whether a node supports the specified feature. Similar to the DOMImplementation.hasFeature method and takes the same feature names. If version is null, returns true if any version of the feature is supported.
method.description: Returns true if the specified feature and version are supported.
method.return-description: Returns true if the specified feature and version are supported.

method.name: normalize

browser.description: May crash IE 6.0.

method.remarks:
Normalizes any Text nodes contained under this node and all of its children. Merges any adjacent Text nodes into one object, so that the nodes reflect how they would be structured if this XML document were freshly loaded.

Normalize() is useful for manipulating the text content of nodes for editing. Instead of worrying about altering existing Text nodes, you can simply add new nodes and perform the normalize when you finish your updates.
method.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/splittext.html
method.description: Merges text nodes adjacent to the element to create a normalized DOM.

method.name: removeChild

parameter.name: oldChild
parameter.description: Child node to remove.

exception.description: Raises a NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR if the node is read-only.
Raises a NOT_FOUND_ERR if the supplied node is not a child of this one.

method.example:
Using removeChild

var obj=document.Document.getElementById('EmailAddress');
                    try {
                    var oldChild=obj.removeChild(obj.Node.firstChild);
                    } catch DOMException {
                    // Error handling
                    };

For more examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/movingnodes.html
method.remarks: Removes and returns the specified child node from the list of this node's children.
method.description: Removes the specified child node from the element and returns the node.
method.return-description: Removes the specified child node from the element and returns the node.

method.name: replaceChild

parameter.name: newChild
parameter.description: Node to replace the oldChild node with.

parameter.name: oldChild
parameter.description: Node to be replaced.

exception.description: Raises a HIERARCHY_REQUEST_ERR error if either the node being inserted is one of this node's ancestors, or if the current node does not allow this type of node as a child.
Raises a WRONG_DOCUMENT_ERR error if the newChild node was not created within the current document.
Raises a NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR if this node is read-only or if the parent of the new node is read-only.
Raises a NOT_FOUND_ERR if the supplied oldChild node is not a child of this one.

method.example:
Using replaceChild

var obj=document.Document.getElementById('EmailAddress');
                    var newElement=document.Document.createElement('label');
                    try {
                    var oldChild=obj.replaceChild(newElement, obj.Node.lastChild);
                    } catch DOMException {
                    // Error handling
                    };

For more examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/movingnodes.html
method.remarks:
This method simplifies the process of calling removeChild and then insertBefore, so that you do not have to worry if this node is the first or last child.

The new child node is removed if it already exists somewhere else in the DOM tree. If the new child is a DocumentFragment node, the oldChild node is replaced by all of the nodes within the DocumentFragment, in the same order.
method.description: Removes the specified child node, replaces it with another node, and returns the removed node.
method.return-description: Returns the replaced oldChild node.

class.remarks:
This object represents a unique node within a DOM tree. It is the lowest-level unit for representing the contents of an XML document, from which more specific types are derived. Perhaps the most commonly used derivitives of Node are Element, Attribute and Text.

You will never actually create a node directly as it is intended to be a basic interface for more specific classes, but nevertheless the properties and methods defined here are available in many different DOM objects.

class.description: Filters the nodes of a document tree.

constructor.description: Filters the nodes of a document tree.

method.name: acceptNode
method.remarks: Returns one of the following three values: 1=FILTER_ACCEPT (accept the node), 2=FILTER_REJECT (reject the node), 3=FILTER_SKIP (skip the node).
method.description: Defines a node filter and returns one of the three NodeFilter constants.
method.return-description: Returns a constant. See Remarks for possible values.

class.description: Iterates through a set of Document nodes.

constructor.description: Iterates through a set of Document nodes.

property.name: expandEntityReferences
property.description: If true, indicates that the NodeIterator traverses the children of EntityReference nodes.

property.name: filter
property.description: Node filter function associated with the NodeIterator.

property.name: root
property.description: Root node for the NodeIterator to start iterating with.

property.name: whatToShow
property.description: Set of flags specifying which nodes to include in the node filter.

method.name: detach
method.description: Detaches the NodeIterator from the document.

method.name: nextNode
method.description: Returns the next node in the filtered set of nodes.
method.return-description: Returns the next node in the filtered set of nodes.

method.name: previousNode
method.description: Returns the previous node in the filtered set of nodes.
method.return-description: Returns the previous node in the filtered set of nodes.

class.description: Collection of nodes accessible by index.

constructor.description: Collection of nodes accessible by index.

property.name: length
property.remarks: Number of nodes contained within this NodeList. If no nodes are in this list, returns 0.
property.description: The number of nodes in this list.

method.name: item

parameter.name: index
parameter.description: Index number to retrieve.

method.example:
Using item

for (var idx=0; idx < node.Node.childNodes.length; idx++) {
                    var curNode=node.Node.childNodes.item(idx);
                    }

For more examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/item.html
method.remarks: Returns the node contained within this NodeList at the given index number. The index values start counting at 0, and a null value will be returned if an invalid index is supplied.
method.description: Returns the node contained at the specified index.
method.return-description: Returns the node contained at the specified index.

class.remarks:
A NodeList is a sort of array which is used to contain a collection of nodes. It is commonly used throughout the DOM objects as a way of returning a list of nodes, whether as a listing of Node.attributes bound to an Element, or as a list of Node.childNodes.

Though in principle this object is similar to an Array, it is merely a very rudimentary form, and as such there is no relationship between the two objects. The list of methods and properties a NodeList supports is quite small in comparison.

class.description: Represents an XML Notation in a document.

constructor.description: Represents an XML Notation in a document.

property.name: publicId
property.remarks: If a public identifier was used within this notation (e.g. ]]>), then the public component (in this example, the "gif viewer" string) will be assigned to this property.
property.description: Public identifier for this notation, if specified.

property.name: systemId
property.remarks: If a system identifier was used in this notation (for instance, if this notation represents the path to the application a specific processing instruction is intended for), that value is stored in this property. It is null if no system identifier was supplied.
property.description: System identifier for this notation, if specified.

class.remarks: This object represents a DTD notation. Notations are used in XML documents for defining entity and attribute-list declarations, among other aspects of DTDs (Document Type Definition), and appear like <!NOTATION name ...>. They can be used to identify the format of unparsed entities, elements with a notation attribute, or specific processing instructions.

class.description: Represents a Processing Instruction in an XML document.

constructor.description: Represents a Processing Instruction in an XML document.

property.name: data
property.remarks: Represents the content data of a processing instruction. This is the entire text between the target name and the closing ?> tag. Setting this value throws an exception if this node is marked as read-only.
property.description: PI data or content
property.example:
For examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/data.html

property.name: target
property.remarks: This is the name of this processing instruction. This is the text immediately following <? and and before the data.
property.description: PI target name

class.remarks: Represents a Processing Instruction, which is a way to keep document processing information inside an XML document. For instance, instructions on which stylesheets to apply can be defined in a processing instruction, even though that isn't directly related to the content of the document.

class.description: Represents a range of nodes within a document.

constructor.description: Represents a range of nodes within a document.

property.name: collapsed
property.description: If true, indicates that the range is collapsed.

property.name: commonAncestorContainer
property.description: Deepest nested node in the document that contains both the start and end points of the range.

property.name: endContainer
property.description: Document node that contains the end point of the range.

property.name: endOffset
property.description: End position of the range in the endContainer.

property.name: startContainer
property.description: Document node that contains the start point of the range.

property.name: startOffset
property.description: Position of the start point of the range in the startContainer.

method.name: cloneContents
method.remarks: Similar to extractContents, this method copies the contents of this Range into a new DocumentFragment but leaves the original intact.
method.description: Creates a new DocumentFragment that contains a copy of the document contents for the specified Range.
method.return-description: Returns a new DocumentFragment.

method.name: cloneRange
method.remarks: Creates a new Range whose boundaries are equal to the current Range.
method.description: Creates a copy of the specified Range.
method.return-description: Returns a new Range object.

method.name: collapse

parameter.name: toStart
parameter.description: If true, collapses the Range onto its start; otherwise it collapses on its end.

method.remarks: Collapses the Range onto one of its boundary points (e.g. Start or End).
method.description: Collapses the Range.

method.name: compareBoundaryPoints

parameter.name: how
parameter.description: Code for how to compare the two boundary points of the range. 0=START_TO_START, 1=START_TO_END, 2=END_TO_END, 3=END_TO_START.

parameter.name: sourceRange
parameter.description: Range to be compared to this range.

method.remarks: Compare the boundary points of two Ranges in a document. Similar to the "<=>" compare operator in many languages, it returns -1, 0 or 1 depending on whether the boundary points of the Range is respectively before (-1), equal to (0) or after (1) the corresponding boundary points of the given Range.
method.description: Compares the specified set of boundary points.
method.return-description: Returns -1 if the boundary points of this Range are before those of the specified Range. Returns 0 if the boundary points are equal. Returns 1 if the boundary points of this Range are after those of the specified Range.

method.name: deleteContents
method.remarks: Removes the contents of the Range from its containing Document (or DocumentFragment). Note that the affected nodes are not returned, but are simply silently removed.
method.description: Deletes the contents of the document for the specified Range.

method.name: detach
method.remarks: Called to indicate that this range is no longer in use, and can be cleaned up. Any subsequent calls to this range will raise a DOMException.
method.description: Stops the implementation of the range.

method.name: extractContents
method.remarks: Moves the contents of the Range from it's containing Document (or DocumentFragment) into a new DocumentFragment.
method.description: Extracts, deletes, and returns the contents of the Range as a DocumentFragment.
method.return-description: Returns a DocumentFragment.

method.name: insertNode

parameter.name: newNode
parameter.description: Node to insert.

method.remarks: Inserts a node into the containing Document or DocumentFragment at the start of the Range. If the container is a Text node, this will be split at the start of the Range (as if the Text node's splitText method was performed at the insertion point) and insertion will occur between the two resulting Text nodes. Adjacent Text nodes will not be merged. If the given node is a DocumentFragment node, its children will be inserted rather than the given node itself.
method.description: Inserts the specified node at the starting point for the Range.

method.name: selectNode

parameter.name: refNode
parameter.description: Node to select.

method.remarks: Selects the specified node and its contents.
method.description: Sets the boundary points of the Range to contain the node and its descendants.

method.name: selectNodeContents

parameter.name: refNode
parameter.description: Node to select the contents of.

method.remarks: Selects the contents of the specified node.
method.description: Sets the boundary points of the Range to contain the descendants of a node, but not the actual node.

method.name: setEnd

parameter.name: refNode
parameter.description: Node at the end of the range. Cannot be null.

parameter.name: offset
parameter.description: Value to set the end of the offset at.

method.remarks: Sets the end point of a Range.
method.description: Sets the end point of the Range as specified by node and offset.

method.name: setEndAfter

parameter.name: refNode
parameter.description: Node to set the end after.

method.description: Sets the end point of the range to immediately after the specified node.

method.name: setEndBefore

parameter.name: refNode
parameter.description: Node to set the end before.

method.description: Sets the end point of the range to immediately before the specified node.

method.name: setStart

parameter.name: refNode
parameter.description: Node for the start point of the range. Cannot be null.

parameter.name: offset
parameter.description: Value to set the start of the offset from.

method.description: Sets the start point of the range to the specified position within the specified node.

method.name: setStartAfter

parameter.name: refNode
parameter.description: Node to set the start point after.

method.description: Sets the start point of the range to immediately after the specified node.

method.name: setStartBefore

parameter.name: refNode
parameter.description: Node to set the start point before.

method.description: Sets the start point of the range to immediately before the specified node.

method.name: surroundContents

parameter.name: newParent
parameter.description: Node to use as the new parent node.

method.remarks: Reparents the contents of the Range to the given node and inserts the node at the position of the start of the Range.
method.description: Inserts the specified node and makes it a parent to the nodes in the Range.

method.name: toString
method.description: Returns the document contents of the Range as a plain text string.
method.return-description: Returns the document contents of the Range as a plain text string.

class.description: Represents a text node in a document.

constructor.description: Represents a text node in a document.

method.name: splitText

parameter.name: offset
parameter.description: Number of characters from the beginning of the text string to split the node.

exception.description: Raises an INDEX_SIZE_ERR error if the offset supplied to this method is negative or is greater than the number of characters in this node.
Raises a NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR error if this node is read-only.

method.example:
Using splitText

/* Given the source XML, bold the word "everything":
                    
Life, the universe, and everything

                    */
                    var element=document.Document.getElementById('title');
                    var textNode1=element.Node.childNodes[0];
                    if (textNode1.Node.nodeType == Node.Node.TEXT_NODE) {
                    var offset=textNode1.CharacterData.data.String.indexOf('everything');
                    var textNode2=textNode1.splitText(offset);
                    var boldElement=element.Node.appendChild(document.Document.createElement('b'));
                    boldElement.Node.appendChild(textNode2);
                    }

For more examples, see the quirksmode test page:

http://www.quirksmode.org/dom/tests/splittext.html
method.remarks:
This method is used to split a Text node into two halves, split on a specific character offset. The second half of the text is returned as a new Text node, and is automatically inserted adjacent to the first one in the DOM tree. This method results in no visual change, except the text nodes can be modified to change the structure of the text (e.g. wrapping a block of text in another element, like an HTML "bold" tag).

Manipulating text content is possible by using some of the methods on the CharacterData object, but this is usually more work than developers want to go through. This method provides a convenience method for a common pattern in manipulating DOM text.
method.description: Splits this node into two adjacent nodes at the given offset
method.return-description: Returns a Text or textNode object.

class.remarks:
This object interface represents the text contents, or character data, of an Element or Attr object.

If an Element only has text and no other elements as its children, then there will be a single Text node representing all this content. Assuming there are other elements as it's children however, there will be multiple Text nodes separating the Element objects from each other. It is also possible for multiple Text nodes to be adjacent to one another, though when the document is saved (or when the parent Node's Node.normalize method is invoked) these multiple Text nodes will be merged into one.
